title: 111_hr5770
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arctic Marine Shipping Assessment Implementation Act of 2010". The Congress declares the Arctic Ocean and adjacent seas are becoming more accessible to shipping due to thinning ice cover and technological advancements. It is in the interests of the United States to ensure safe shipping in the Arctic while protecting the natural environment and respecting the needs of Arctic resource users. The United States aims to collaborate with Alaska and Arctic neighbors to ensure safe and secure shipping in the Arctic Ocean, protect the environment and wildlife, respect sovereign and security interests, allow access for research vessels, and maintain peaceful relations in the region. The United States aims to establish international cooperation for reliable shipping in the Arctic, including investments in navigation aids, ports of refuge, communication, mapping, and search and rescue capabilities to support peaceful relations and access for research vessels. The United States seeks international cooperation for safe Arctic shipping, including investments in navigation aids, ports of refuge, communication, mapping, and search and rescue capabilities. Mariners have sought benefits from Arctic sea routes for centuries, similar to the Panama and Suez canals, but expanded shipping poses risks to Arctic residents. Coordinated shipping regulations are necessary to protect U.S. interests in the region. The United States has proven models for international cooperation in managing regional waterways, such as joint administration of the St. Lawrence Seaway with Canada and cooperation with Russia for fisheries enforcement in the Bering Sea. The country has interests in the Arctic that rely on icebreaker platforms, with a need to replace older icebreakers. Sovereign interests in the Arctic Ocean and Bering Sea regions may increase with a United States claim for an extended continental shelf. Building new icebreakers and international plans are essential. The Polar Class icebreakers from the 1970s need replacement to protect United States interests in the Arctic Ocean and Bering Sea regions. Building new icebreakers and establishing international cooperation for shipping regulations and oil spill prevention are essential, especially with the completion of an Arctic Marine Shipping Assessment by the Arctic Council. The completion of an Arctic Marine Shipping Assessment by the Arctic Council is crucial for protecting United States interests in the Arctic Ocean and adjacent seas due to extensive current vessel use by many nations. Starting efforts now is necessary, considering the long lead times required for organization. The Arctic Marine Shipping Assessment by the Arctic Council is important for protecting US interests in the Arctic Ocean and adjacent seas. Starting efforts now is crucial due to the long lead times required for organization. The purpose of this section is to ensure safe maritime shipping in the Arctic, including aids to navigation, vessel escorts, spill response capability, and search and rescue. The Secretary of the department operating the Coast Guard is encouraged to negotiate agreements through the International Maritime Organization to promote coordinated action among Arctic nations for navigation aids, marine safety, oil spill prevention, and maritime domain awareness. The Committee on the Maritime Transportation System coordinates domestic transportation policies in the Arctic to ensure aids to navigation, marine safety, oil spill prevention, maritime domain awareness, and search and rescue. The Secretary of the department operating the Coast Guard may negotiate agreements for these purposes. The Secretary of Transportation, established under a directive of the President in the Ocean Action Plan, shall coordinate domestic transportation policies in the Arctic. Agreements, contracts, and grants may be entered into to carry out the purpose of this section. Icebreaking for safe maritime navigation and demonstration projects are also part of the responsibilities. The Secretary of Transportation coordinates Arctic transportation policies and may enter agreements for icebreaking and demonstration projects to reduce emissions and train mariners for Arctic operations. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for seasonal operations in the Arctic, training mariners for ice navigation, and conducting demonstration projects to reduce emissions. Additionally, funding is allocated for icebreakers to support Arctic operations. Authorization of appropriations is provided for icebreakers to support Arctic operations, including conducting cost-benefit analyses for extending the service life of the existing fleet. The Commandant of the Coast Guard is required to conduct a cost-benefit analysis of extending the service life of existing icebreakers, building new ones, or a combination of both for carrying out Federal icebreaking missions. Additionally, an analysis of the impact on mission capacity and the ability of the United States to operate is also mandated. The Commandant of the Coast Guard must analyze the cost and benefits of extending the service life of current icebreakers or building new ones for Federal icebreaking missions. They also need to assess the impact on mission capacity and the ability of the United States to operate in the Arctic regions by 2020 if icebreaker fleet recapitalization is not fully funded. The Commandant of the Coast Guard must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of the Act or the completion of the High Latitude Study on Arctic ice-breaking mission requirements. This report will contain study results and recommendations for the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation and the House of Representatives Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. The Commandant of the Coast Guard is required to submit reports with analysis results and recommendations to Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment, as per section 93(a)(24) of title 14, United States Code. The reports will be sent to the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation and the House of Representatives Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. The Coast Guard must assess the need for increased presence in high latitude regions. The Secretary of the department overseeing the Coast Guard must submit a report within 270 days to assess the need for additional Coast Guard capabilities in high latitude regions, covering search and rescue, pollution response, fisheries enforcement, and maritime commerce. The report should include evaluations of current assets and projected needs for forward operating bases in these regions. The report must assess the high latitude operating capabilities of current Coast Guard assets, projected needs for forward operating bases, shore infrastructure, personnel, logistics, communications, and resources requirements. It should also evaluate the need for high latitude icebreaking capability and the performance of current icebreaking assets. The report will assess the need for high latitude icebreaking capability, including the performance of current icebreaking assets and their material condition. It will also provide a detailed estimate of acquisition costs for additional prevention and response capability in high latitude regions. The report will include a detailed estimate of acquisition costs for high latitude icebreaking assets, operations, and maintenance costs for a 10-year period to ensure mission performance goals are met. It will also cover the renovation and modernization of the Coast Guard's assets. The report will provide detailed cost estimates for high latitude icebreaking capability over a 10-year period, including renovating and modernizing the existing fleet and replacing it. SEC. 5. ARCTIC DEFINITION. The term "Arctic" in this Act refers to the definition in the Arctic Research and Policy Act of 1984.
